keyTakeAways: A fire broke out at Hungary's main oil refinery, the Danube Refinery in Százhalombatta, on Monday night.
No injuries were reported; emergency protocols were followed, and unaffected units are being restarted.
The cause of the fire is under investigation, and the incident highlights ongoing risks in energy infrastructure.
Hungary continues to rely heavily on Russian oil, despite the EU's efforts to phase out Russian energy imports post-2022.
Hungary’s strategic reserves may be considered to ensure domestic fuel supply during disruptions.
Air quality around the refinery has been continuously monitored, with no readings exceeding health limits.
The facility is the country’s only major crude-processing site and primarily processes oil from Russia.
Prime Minister Viktor Orbán confirmed fuel supplies are secure and emphasized thorough investigation of the incident.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fire broke out overnight at Hungary’s Danube Refinery in Százhalombatta, prompting emergency response and raising concerns about fuel supply and energy security. Despite no injuries reported, the incident underscores Hungary’s continued reliance on Russian oil, which contrasts with the EU’s broader policy of phasing out Russian energy imports since 2022. The cause of the fire is under investigation, and MOL, Hungary’s state-owned energy company, has confirmed that emergency protocols were followed and that domestic fuel supply is secure. Air quality has been monitored and remains within safe limits. Prime Minister Viktor Orbán affirmed that fuel supplies are stable and emphasized the need for a thorough investigation. This event highlights both the vulnerability of critical energy infrastructure and Hungary’s divergence from EU energy transition policies.
title: Fire at Hungary’s Main Oil Refinery Raises Energy Security Concerns Amid EU’s Russian Oil Phase-Out
